H0.text: Three is the number of families into which known quarks are divided.

H1.text: Two is the number of families into which quarks are known to be divided.

H2.text: Five is the number of families into which known quarks are divided.

H3.text: Four is the number of families into which known quarks are divided.

A4.text: Elementary fermions are grouped into three generations, each comprising two leptons and two quarks.

A5.text: All searches for a fourth generation of quarks and other elementary fermions have failed, and there is strong indirect evidence that no more than three generations exist.
